en.gameplay/time_device/description: This is your Time Device. You may use it to advance in time to discover how the Time Saboteur affected the people in this scene.
en.gameplay/hud/mission_log_warning/say_0: You need to talk to everyone!
en.gameplay/pop_up/time_device_available/sa: Your Time Device is now available to use!
en.popup/not_all_anomalies: Ainda faltam anomalias para serem descobertas
en.gameplay/pop_up/wrong_anomaly/say_0: Director: Watch it! This person is not an anomaly!
en.gameplay/pop_up/wrong_saboteur/say_0: Director: Oh no! This person is not the saboteur!/nQuickly, go back in time before you ruin the Time Line! Next time, be careful and confront the actual saboteur!
en.gameplay/level_1/pop_up/tutorial_1/say_0: Director: You are now on the field, Agent!/nInvestigate the scene and make sure to talk to all the people available./nFor each person that you talk to, an entry will be available on your Mission Log. /nIf you need to remember the purpose of your mission, check the Mission Prompt./nOnce you get all the entries on your Mission Log, you may use the Time Device to proceed to the next step of your mission.
en.gameplay/level_1/pop_up/tutorial_2/say_0: Director: Now it's time to do what you came here for!/nLook for whoever seems to have their mind disrupted and mark them as anomalies!/nOnce you do this part, confront the Time Saboteur and put an end to his naughtiness!/nBut remember: you can only fulfill your mission once you detected correctly all the anomalies.
en.gameplay/level_1/mission_prompt/content: Mission Prompt: The People's Election (1828)/nLocation: Nashville, Tennessee (Town Square), 1828/nThe nation enters the election of 1828 carrying unresolved anger. In 1824, Andrew Jackson won the popular vote but lost the presidency when the House of Representatives selected John Quincy Adams, an outcome Jackson condemned as a “Corrupt Bargain.” Public trust in the political system was shaken, and that resentment has not faded./n/nNow it returns with force. Property requirements for voting have largely been abolished, bringing thousands of white laborers and small farmers into the electorate for the first time. This “Common Man” sees Jackson as his representative./n/nTo organize this new political reality, a permanent party structure is emerging. The Democratic Party is taking shape as the first modern political machine, built to mobilize mass participation and sustain popular power beyond a single election./nTo organize this new political reality, a permanent party structure is emerging. The Democratic Party is taking shape as the first modern political machine, built to mobilize mass participation and sustain popular power beyond a single election./nExpected Outcome: Jackson wins decisively, inaugurating the Jacksonian Era and establishing the Democratic Party as a dominant national force./nObjective: A Saboteur is disrupting the party’s organization in an attempt to prevent Jackson’s rise. Identify and neutralize this interference before it fractures the movement and alters the nation’s political future.
en.gameplay/level_1/mission_log/kid_eddie: Eddie Malone: Enthusiastic newsboy. Stance: Loves the excitement and the <q >party for the poor<q > angle.
en.gameplay/level_1/mission_log/silas: Silas Cobb: Merchant. Stance: Supporter. Sees the Party as a voice for workers.
en.gameplay/level_1/mission_log/judge_thorn: Judge Thorne: Elite. Stance: Opponent. Sees the Party as a dangerous mob.
en.gameplay/level_1/mission_log/young_tom: Young Tom: Confused teen. Stance: Neutral/Clueless. Just here for the food.
en.gameplay/level_1/mission_log/elias: Elias Vance: Organizer. Stance: Architect. Speaks of <q > building the party machine.<q >
en.gameplay/level_1/mission_log/old_jeb: Old Jeb: Veteran. Stance: Jackson Loyalist.
en.gameplay/level_1/mission_log/patrick: Patrick O'Neil: Immigrant. Stance: Grateful for inclusion.
en.gameplay/level_1/pop-up/elias_flees: Elias opened a Time Vortex Portal and fled.
en.gameplay/level_2/mission_prompt/briefing: Mission Prompt: Sovereignty & Sorrow (1832)/nNew Echota, Capital of the Cherokee Nation (Georgia), 1832/nWhile national politics reshape democracy, a constitutional crisis unfolds on the frontier. Georgia, seeking Cherokee lands rich in gold and agriculture, has passed laws dissolving the Cherokee government. The intent is clear. Legal erasure precedes physical removal./nThe result is a breakdown of constitutional balance. The law stands. Enforcement does not./nExpected Outcome: Jackson’s inaction leads, in 1838, to the forced removal known as the Trail of Tears. The suffering is immense, but the Cherokee Nation survives in exile./nObjective: The Saboteur aims to provoke an immediate armed conflict, turning legal frustration into catastrophe. Prevent escalation. Contain the crisis before it becomes a massacre history has not yet reached.
en.gameplay/level_2/mission_log/teen_eddie: Young Reporter. Stance: Worried observer. Notes the divide between Whigs and Democrats.
en.gameplay/level_2/mission_log/wise_wolf: Cherokee Leader. Stance: Legal Hopeful. Trusts the Court over the Party.
en.gameplay/level_2/mission_log/rev_hale: Missionary. Stance: Moral Opponent. Critiques <q > Progress.<q >
en.gameplay/level_2/mission_log/little_bear: Cherokee Child. Stance: Innocent/Confused. Thinks the removal is a trip
en.gameplay/level_2/mission_log/lt_draven: Soldier. Stance: Enforcer. Believes in <q > Majority Will<q >  (Expansion).
en.gameplay/level_2/mission_log/ian: Land Agent. Stance: Pragmatist. Suggests a treaty to avoid conflict.
en.gameplay/level_2/pop-up/ian_flees: Ian (Elias) opened a Time Vortex Portal and fled again.
en.gameplay/level_3/mission_prompt/briefing: Mission Prompt: The Bank War (1833)/nPhiladelphia, Pennsylvania (Chestnut Street), 1833/nEconomic power becomes the next battleground. The Second Bank of the United States controls credit and currency, stabilizing the economy while concentrating financial influence. Jackson views the Bank as an engine of privilege, favoring the wealthy Northeast over the agrarian South and West./nIn 1833, he acts. Jackson vetoes the renewal of the Bank’s charter on political grounds, expanding presidential authority and igniting the conflict known as the Bank War. The nation polarizes, and opposition consolidates into the Whig Party, which denounces Jackson as 'King Andrew I'./nExpected Outcome: The Bank is dismantled. Financial instability follows, contributing to the Panic of 1837. The crisis is severe, but the Republic endures./nObjective: The Saboteur is exploiting economic fear to incite class-based violence and attacks on financial institutions. Keep the conflict political. Prevent economic unrest from collapsing into social chaos.
en.gameplay/level_3/mission_log/adult_eddie: Eddie Malone: Kiosk Owner. Stance: Entrepreneur. Sees the political fight as good for business.
en.gameplay/level_3/mission_log/thaddeus: Thaddeus Sterling: Banker. Stance: Elite Whig. Defends the Bank against the <q >mob<q >.
en.gameplay/level_3/mission_log/congressman: Congressman Miller: Democrat. Stance: Populist. Wants to destroy the Bank for the <q >people<q >.
en.gameplay/level_3/mission_log/timmy: Timmy: Chimney Sweep. Stance: Confused. Doesn't understand paper money vs. coins.
en.gameplay/level_3/mission_log/arthur: Arthur Pen: Cartoonist. Stance: Neutral Cynic. Profiting from polarization.
en.gameplay/level_3/mission_log/ivan: Ivan E. Scale: Consultant. Stance: Doom-sayer. Predicts market collapse.
en.gameplay/level_4/pop-up/the_party_system: The Party System: The Jacksonian Era created the modern model of political parties.
en.gameplay/level_4/pop-up/democrats: Democrats: Jackson's party solidified defending the <q >common man<q > (white), but carrying the stains of slavery and removal.
en.gameplay/level_4/pop-up/whigs: Whigs: Emerged to oppose Jackson, defending Congress and economic modernization.
en.level_0/intro_dialogue/director/line_0/s: The Line of Time, Agent 7. It’s supposed to be a steady path of growth, struggle, and eventual union. But lately? It’s fraying.
The Jacksonian Era is the foundation of modern American politics. If it cracks, the whole house falls
en.level_0/intro_dialogue/protagonist/line_: We’ve seen ripples since the 1824 election. People are calling it 'The Saboteur's Work.' Is he that much of a threat?
en.level_0/intro_dialogue/director/line_1/s: The Time Patrol exists for one reason: to ensure the past remains the past. We aren't here to make history better; we are here to keep it real.
This Saboteur isn't just changing a vote here or there. He’s trying to trigger a premature Civil War.
He wants to replace Jackson’s populism with a violent mob revolt, turn the Cherokee removal into a total genocide, and crash the economy decades before the Panic of 1837.
en.level_0/intro_dialogue/protagonist/line_: If he succeeds, the United States of America won't survive to see the 20th century.
en.level_0/intro_dialogue/director/line_2/s: Exactly. History would become a graveyard of 'what-ifs.' No democracy, no superpower, just chaos.
We’ve tracked his signature to Nashville, 1828. He’s already in place, poisoning the minds of the people, hiding behind the formation of the Democratic Party.
en.level_0/intro_dialogue/protagonist/line_: I’m ready. I’ll find him, and I'll fix the anomalies.
en.level_0/intro_dialogue/director/line_3/s: Listen to me, 7. You’re going into a world of mud, ink, and raw anger. It’s loud, it’s messy, and it’s dangerous.
But remember: the billions of souls in the future are breathing because the past happened exactly the way it did.
You are the invisible shield of the Republic. You are the only thing standing between a functioning democracy and a dark age of tyranny.
We are the Watchers of the Time. The weight of the timeline is on your shoulders now. Don't let it break.
en.level_0/intro_dialogue/protagonist/line_: I won't let you down, Director.
en.level_0/intro_dialogue/director/line_4/s: Don't worry about me. Worry about the future. Now, jump. Nashville is waiting.
en.level_1/day_1/kid_eddie/say_2: Read all about the Great Rematch! Adams calls us a mob; we call ourselves the Democracy! It's a whole new party, folks, organized like an army to put Old Hickory in the big chair!
en.level_1/day_1/kid_eddie/say_3: (Whispering) Ye look like a stranger, sir.
en.level_1/day_1/kid_eddie/say_4: (Whispering) Watch yer step. The ground ain't shakin' from an earthquake, it’s the people marchin'.
en.level_1/day_1/silas/say_0: For twenty years I’ve paid my dues but couldn't vote.
en.level_1/day_1/silas/say_1: Now, this new Democratic Party says my voice counts as much as a banker's.
en.level_1/day_1/silas/say_2: We need a man who knows the price of grain, not some dandy who speaks Latin.
en.level_1/day_1/silas/say_3: We need a man who can fight for the people, not some dandy with a fancy hat.
en.level_1/day_1/judge_thorne/say_0: They call it a 'Party'? I call it a gang.
en.level_1/day_1/judge_thorne/say_1: This 'Democratic' machine relies on rallies and hickory poles instead of debate. If Jackson wins, he’ll turn the White House into a stable for his donkey supporters.
en.level_1/day_1/young_tom/say_0: Pa said we came for liberty, but I just heard there was free cider and barbecue.
en.level_1/day_1/young_tom/say_1: Do I have to join the Party to get a rib? I don't even know what a 'veto' is.
en.level_1/day_1/elias/say_0: They robbed us in '24, but in '28, we are organized.
en.level_1/day_1/elias/say_1: We are building a machine, friend. A party that outlives any single man.
en.level_1/day_1/elias/say_2: We call it the Democratic Party, and it shall be the sword of the common man forever.
en.level_1/day_1/old_jeb/say_0: I don't care about parties, I care about the General! But if this 'Democrat' ticket gets him in, I'll wear the badge.
en.level_1/day_1/patrick/say_0: Finally, a party that welcomes the Irish! Adams wants us out, but the Democrats say we belong.
en.level_1/day_2/kid_eddie/say_0: Still sellin' like hotcakes! The people love the idea of a party for the poor man. Adams is scared, I can tell!
en.level_1/day_2/judge_thorne/say_0: My point stands. Look at them, shouting like animals. This 'Democracy' will be the end of civilized government.
en.level_1/day_2/young_tom/say_0: I found the cider! But... why is Mr. Silas crying over there? Did they run out of ribs?
en.level_1/day_2/silas/say_0: I... I took the posters down.
en.level_1/day_2/silas/say_1: A good sir told me the Democrats plan to abolish private property!
en.level_1/day_2/silas/say_2: Said the Party wants to share my store with everyone. That ain't liberty, that's theft!
en.level_1/day_2/old_jeb/say_1: The Democratic Party has a secret rule: 'Native Born Only'. They used us for the votes, now they'll ship us back to the famine.
en.level_1/day_2/elias/say_0: It is not merely about Jackson.
en.level_1/day_2/elias/say_2: It is about forging a party that stands for the common man against the Washington aristocrats.
en.level_1/confrontation_dialogue/elias/lin: You should be out there cheerin'. History is in the makin'.
en.level_1/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: You're poisoning the very party you helped build, Elias.
I've seen the lies you told the people.
en.level_1/confrontation_dialogue/elias/lin: You think Jackson is a hero because your history books were written by his winners.
I’ve seen the Trail of Tears. I've seen the fire he lights that eventually burns this Union in 1861.
I am stopping the disaster before it starts.
en.level_1/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: You're breaking the timeline for your own judgment.
en.level_1/confrontation_dialogue/elias/lin: I am trying to kill the monster in the crib!
This Party becomes a juggernaut. It survives for centuries, dividing the nation.
If I break the coalition now… turn the workers and immigrants against Jackson… the Party dies today.
en.level_1/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: Not on my watch! You’re coming with me to the Time Patrol Headquarters!
en.level_1/confrontation_dialogue/elias/lin: I am trying to save the future from a tyrant.
This is not over young boy…
en.level_2/day_1/teen_eddie/say_1: The Whigs are yelling that Jackson is a tyrant for ignoring the law, but the Democrats are cheering for more land! It's a party line split, folks!
en.level_2/day_1/teen_eddie/say_2: (Whispering) Strange to see you here, traveler.
en.level_2/day_1/teen_eddie/say_3: (Whispering) The ink is dry on the ruling, but the soldiers look ready to spill red instead of ink.
en.level_2/day_1/wise_wolf/say_0: We thought the Democrats were for the 'little guy'.
en.level_2/day_1/wise_wolf/say_1: But it seems their definition of 'the people' does not include us, who stood here in this land before all.
en.level_2/day_1/wise_wolf/say_2: Still, the Law is colorless. The Supreme Court is our last hope.
en.level_2/day_1/rev_hale/say_0: I spoke to the local Democratic leaders.
en.level_2/day_1/rev_hale/say_2: I told them progress without soul is just greed. They didn't listen.
en.level_2/day_1/little_bear/say_0: My father is packing our blankets. He says we might go on a 'Great Walk' soon. Is it like a hunting trip? I hope I can bring my pony.
en.level_2/day_1/lt_draven/say_0: The Party platform is clear: Westward Expansion.
en.level_2/day_1/lt_draven/say_1: The President was elected to open this land for white farmers. I'm just following the will of the majority.
en.level_2/day_1/ian/say_0: The Party is in a bind.
en.level_2/day_1/ian/say_1: If Jackson enforces the Court's ruling, he loses the support of the South. If he ignores it, he breaks the law.
en.level_2/day_1/ian/say_2: A tragedy... but perhaps a signed treaty solves everyone's headache?
en.level_2/day_2/teen_eddie/say_1: The Whigs in Washington are furious, but out here? The soldiers look ready to march.
en.level_2/day_2/rev_hale/say_1: The President is stubborn, but he is not a monster. He won't order a slaughter...
en.level_2/day_2/little_bear/say_1: The man with the map looked at me and smiled, but it was a scary smile.
en.level_2/day_2/wise_wolf/say_1: The savages are planning a riot.
en.level_2/day_2/wise_wolf/say_2: The Party can't wait for D.C. We clear the threat permanently. No prisoners.
en.level_2/day_2/wise_wolf/say_3: Tonight. We must strike first! Burn the town!
en.level_2/day_2/lt_draven/say_0: That Agent, Cleave, he intercepted their messages.
en.level_2/day_2/ian/say_1: The Supreme Court has spoken, yes... but I have friends in the White House who say the army is coming regardless.
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: You're turning a tragedy into a massacre, Ian S. Cleave... or should I say, Elias Vance?
Your little trick could not distract me from who you really are!
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/ian/line_: I am showing the true cost of your 'Manifest Destiny'!
Jackson's Party wants land? Let them pay for it in blood right now, so the future never forgets.
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: You're trying to start a war, Elias.
The history books speak of a forced removal, a tragedy... but you want to start something absurd right here.
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/ian/line_: You cling to your 'books' like a child clings to a blanket.
Yes, the Trail of Tears was a tragedy. A slow, agonizing march of death.
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: And you want to make it worse?
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/ian/line_: Worse? Or faster? If I spark a war today, the pain ends in weeks, not years.
The outcome is the same: the Cherokee lose. I am merely... adjusting the efficiency of the inevitable.
If I spark a war today, the pain ends in weeks, not years on the Trail of Tears.
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: You're manipulating good men into becoming violent. The Trail is a tragedy, but at least the Nation survives it.
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/ian/line_: Survives to be forgotten? I am showing them the truth of this era!
Jackson's democracy is built on bones.
I just want the pile to be high enough that the future can never ignore it. Now step aside.
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: You’re not escaping from me this time, Elias!
en.level_2/confrontation_dialogue/ian/line_: I guess we’ll see each other again, young boy…
en.level_3/day_1/adult_eddie/say_0: Get your prints! The Whigs call him 'King Andrew', but the Democrats call him 'The Dragon Slayer'!
en.level_3/day_1/adult_eddie/say_1: The parties are fightin' over your wallet, folks!
en.level_3/day_1/adult_eddie/say_2: (Whispering) <q >You again? You truly are a ghost of history.
en.level_3/day_1/adult_eddie/say_3: (Whispering) Be careful, the ink on these cartoons is poisoned with hate.
en.level_3/day_1/thaddeus/say_0: This Democratic Party is essentially a mob with a mascot. They think finance is witchcraft.
en.level_3/day_1/thaddeus/say_1: If they kill the Bank, they kill the economy to please their uneducated voters.
en.level_3/day_1/congressman_miller/say_0: The Democratic Party stands for one thing: equality!
en.level_3/day_1/congressman_miller/say_1: Why should a rich Whig in Philly control the money of a Democrat in Tennessee?
en.level_3/day_1/congressman_miller/say_2: The Veto is our declaration of independence from Wall Street!
en.level_3/day_1/timmy/say_0: Mister, my Daddy says this paper money is only good for lightin' fires.
en.level_3/day_1/timmy/say_1: He says only silver coins are real. Is the President gonna take my pennies?
en.level_3/day_1/arthur/say_1: The Democrats want Jackson as a hero protecting the poor; the Whigs want him as a tyrant. Two parties, two realities.
en.level_3/day_1/ivan/say_0: The Democrats are bold, I'll give them that. Challenging the Bank? It's suicidal courage. But markets are fragile things... easily broken.
en.level_3/day_2/adult_eddie/say_0: Prices are wobblin', folks are scared. The cartoon of Jackson fighting the Hydra is selling well, though!
en.level_3/day_2/arthur/say_0: Panic sells papers, my friend. Whether the Bank survives or not, I'll have plenty to draw.
en.level_3/day_2/timmy/say_0: The fancy man told me to run home and tell Pa to buy guns instead of bread. Why?
en.level_3/day_2/thaddeus/say_1: Mr. Scale showed me the drafts.
en.level_3/day_2/thaddeus/say_2: The Democrats plan to physically seize our vaults tomorrow!
en.level_3/day_2/thaddeus/say_3: We must destroy the currency now. Starve the peasants until they beg!
en.level_3/day_2/congressman_miller/say_0: They want blood? We’ll give them blood.
en.level_3/day_2/congressman_miller/say_1: Scale told me the Bank hired assassins to kill Jackson. The Party must become an army.
en.level_3/day_2/congressman_miller/say_2: Burn the Bank! Hang the tellers!
en.level_3/day_2/ivan/say_0: The markets are jittery. A little push... a little rumor about the gold reserves... and the house of cards falls.
en.level_3/day_2/ivan/say_1: The Veto is inevitable. But the aftermath? That is where the opportunity lies.
en.level_3/day_2/ivan/say_3: Chaos is a ladder, my friend.
en.level_3/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: Ivan E. Scale... Elias Vance. Another trick, another attempt to destroy the future.
Stop the press, Elias. You're creating a panic that doesn't belong in this century.
en.level_3/confrontation_dialogue/ivan/line: I am accelerating the inevitable! Jackson kills the Bank, the economy crashes in '37 anyway.
Why wait? If I crash it now, with violence, perhaps the people will reject this 'Democracy' before it becomes unbearable.
I am terrified of the Mob!
Jackson teaches the voters that feelings matter more than facts. Look at your future! It starts here!!
I am trying to cut the root!
en.level_3/confrontation_dialogue/protagoni: Democracy is messy, Elias. But inciting a civil war over a bank isn't the answer.
en.level_4/epilogue/old_eddie/line_0/say_1: But he changed things, America is different now.
en.level_4/epilogue/old_eddie/line_0/say_2: Before him, presidents were distant statues. Now? Every man with dirt under his fingernails thinks the President works for him and we also got two big parties fighting like cats and dogs.
en.level_4/epilogue/old_eddie/line_1/say_0: We thought Jackson was the storm. Turns out, he was just the lightning.
en.level_4/epilogue/old_eddie/line_1/say_1: The thunder... well, that's still rolling.
en.level_4/epilogue/old_eddie/line_1/say_2: Funny thing. Jackson said the Party would protect the people. But now I wonder... who protects the people from the Party?
